Urticaria results from dermal oedema (superficial urticaria) or dermo-hypodermal oedema (deep urticaria or angioedema) due to tissue vasodilatation with increased capillary permeability secondary to the release by mast cells of various mediators, the main one being histamine.

Mast cell activation can occur by 2 mechanisms:
- Immunological: via IgE or IgG-type autoantibodies
- Non-immunological: by direct activation of mast cells via different receptors on their surface or by the direct pharmacological action of certain drugs (e.g. NSAIDs).

question.title: What is the primary mechanism of mast cell activation in urticaria?
question.description: The mechanism of mast cell activation in urticaria

option_a.title: Mast cell activation through direct interaction with IgE antibodies
option_a.description: Mast cell activation through direct interaction with IgE antibodies

option_b.title: Mast cell activation through direct pharmacological action of NSAIDs
option_b.description: Mast cell activation through direct pharmacological action of NSAIDs

option_c.title: Mast cell activation through direct interaction with IgG antibodies
option_c.description: Mast cell activation through direct interaction with IgG antibodies
